reasoning:
The critique targets a load-bearing support for one strand of the paper’s “fussiness” case: in Section 3.2, fat-tailed value-per-resource plus an astronomically large action space is used to argue that (for linear/unbounded views) mostly-great futures require highly specific resource uses. If that strand failed, the overall “no easy eutopia” thesis would be weakened but not collapse, since the paper also leans heavily on (i) multiplicative fragility across many dimensions (Section 2.4), and (ii) bounded-view arguments about bads/goods aggregation (Section 3.3). Hence moderate centrality.

On strength, the objection is conceptually apt—fat tails can indeed create large ‘max of many draws’ gains, and the paper does not explicitly model sampling/search capacity. However it under-engages with key constraints that the paper’s argument implicitly relies on: discovering a high-value configuration is not the same as (a) recognizing it as high value under moral uncertainty, (b) having incentives/power to deploy it across most resources (which linear views require), or (c) avoiding lock-in/path-dependence and political failure modes that prevent adopting the discovered optimum. Also, Forethought’s distribution is conditioned on “no serious coordinated efforts to promote the very best outcomes de dicto”; if that conditioning is taken seriously, assuming massive intentional tail-search partly changes the target distribution rather than refuting conclusions on it. So it weakens but does not refute.

Relevance is fairly high because it engages a Tier-2 core move in the series (fat-tailed value and narrow-target flourishing) and points to an important missing interaction: how optimization/search capacity affects the mapping from ‘rare’ configurations to ‘likely-to-be-found’ outcomes—an issue closely connected to Forethought’s active work on convergence/compromise and optimization pressure. Overall impact is limited (strength×centrality modest), but the critique is directionally useful and conceptually grounded.
title: "Search Optimizes Away Fat-Tailed Obstacles"
